repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
## Problem

Today there is a constraint that these arguments to the `enable` filter be mutually exclusive, but I do not know why such a constraint exists (it is perfectly reasonable to want to enable a capability for just one buffer and just one client).

## Solution

Remove the mutual exclusivity constraint.

This was added in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/35018. cc @ofseed Maybe you can explain why this constraint was added in the first place, perhaps I am missing something.

comment_regular_data.body:
The main reason is that such filters are ambiguous (e.g., should bufnr + client be an AND or OR condition?)

It also aims to prevent the complexity of operations where something is enabled globally but explicitly disabled for one client in one buffer.


> it is perfectly reasonable to want to enable a capability for just one buffer and just one client

This use case likely comes from trying to enable a feature for a single client/buffer in an autocmd, but that's usually unnecessary. Unless the intention is to prevent it from running on other supported buffers/clients, it will avoids enabling it on unsupported clients. It will not create redundant data or autocmds for those buffers.

> The main reason is that such filters are ambiguous (e.g., should bufnr + client be an AND or OR condition?)

I don't think that's a big problem in practice. It's common for API's with multiple filter options to either use AND, or if it also supports OR to make the type of filtering explicit as part of the API.

+1 for supporting both client_id and bufnr in all of the `.enable` APIs - partly because we also document that they can be called as part of an `LspAttach` autocmd handler and that's fired for each client and buffer - so it seems natural that you'd provide both bufnr and client_id and pass them along.

>The main reason is that such filters are ambiguous (e.g., should bufnr + client be an AND or OR condition?)

OR makes no sense in this context so it should be unambiguous. But in any case the current documentation doesn't imply that these options are mutually exclusive.

>This use case likely comes from trying to enable a feature for a single client/buffer in an autocmd, but that's usually unnecessary. Unless the intention is to prevent it from running on other supported buffers/clients, it will avoids enabling it on unsupported clients. It will not create redundant data or autocmds for those buffers.

The fact that it's not strictly necessary is an implementation detail, but from the _interface_ it's not at all obvious that this is the case. These APIs are often called from an `LspAttach` autocommand which is scoped to a buffer and client id, so providing the same scope to any API calls is usually the reasonable thing to do (I don't want my autocommand to have side effects on other unrelated buffers or clients). @mfussenegger already made this point for me above:

>partly because we also document that they can be called as part of an LspAttach autocmd handler and that's fired for each client and buffer - so it seems natural that you'd provide both bufnr and client_id and pass them along.

Perhaps I didn't make myself clear; what I am referring to is a scenario like this:
```lua
vim.lsp.codelens.enable({ bufnr = 0, client_id = 1)}
vim.lsp.codelens.is_enabled({ bufnr = 0}) -- false
```
This is because `is_enabled` follows an AND-like logic; it only returns `true` when it is enabled for every client within a buffer. In this case, the user may think it's an OR.

> These APIs are often called from an `LspAttach` autocommand which is scoped to a buffer and client id, so providing the same scope to any API calls is usually the reasonable thing to do

As I mentioned above, there is no need to enable them one by one in an event like `LspAttach`. When globally enabled via `enable(true)`, its actual behavior is consistent with such an autocmd. It would be good if it worked that way, but I think it's better not mention such use cases in the documentation unless there are specific requirements.

However, if changing the interface to this would feel more natural, I am fine with that. My only concerns lie in cases where different filters are layered or mixed. This is probably a use case that people use fewer than specifying bufnr and client_id together.

> This is because is_enabled follows an AND-like logic; it only returns true when it is enabled for every client within a buffer. In this case, the user may think it's an OR.

Okay that is indeed confusing, but I'd think in your example `is_enabled({ bufnr = 0 })` should have ANY semantics. Feels unintuitive that it would return false if there is a client enabled on that buffer.

With this semantics, we cannot distinguish whether all clients in a buffer are enabled or if a specific client in a buffer is enabled.

Currently, when enabling via `vim.lsp.enable(true, { bufnr = 0 })`, `vim.lsp.is_enabled()` returns false because it returns whether globally enabled. It also does not seem worth losing the ability to differentiate between global and buffer-local enablement by switching it to ANY syntax.

Then, if we keep `vim.lsp.is_enabled()` as ALL syntax but treat `vim.lsp.codelens.is_enabled({ bufnr = 0 })` as ANY syntax, the role of the filter becomes even more ambiguous—this is precisely the semantic ambiguity I mentioned above.

> With this semantics, we cannot distinguish whether all clients in a buffer are enabled or if a specific client in a buffer is enabled.

> Currently, when enabling via vim.lsp.enable(true, { bufnr = 0 }), vim.lsp.is_enabled() returns false because it returns whether globally enabled. It also does not seem worth losing the ability to differentiate between global and buffer-local enablement by switching it to ANY syntax.

But isn't then the confusion mostly around the global case, and not about providing both client_id and bufnr filters?

1. `is_enabled()` is either asking:
    - Is enabled globally
    - Is there any client enabled on any buffer
2. `is_enabled({ bufnr = 1234 })` is either asking:
    - Is it enabled globally for any client (implies it is active on 1234 too)
    - Is any client enabled specifically on bufnr = 1234? (not counting global)
3. `is_enabled({ client_id = 1 })` is either asking:
    - Is client 1 enabled globally
    - Is client 1 enabled on any buffer
4. `is_enabled({ client_id = 1, bufnr = 1234 })` is either asking:
    - Is client 1 enabled globally (it implies it is active on 1234 too)
    - Is client 1 enabled specifically on bufnr = 1234 but not global

For the first three cases, the answer is the first one.

Regarding the fourth case, it queries whether client 1 is enabled on bufnr 1. The result will be true regardless of whether it is enabled globally, specifically for client 1, or specifically for the buffer. This type of minimal-scope query is beneficial as an API for other plugins, whereas the other three queries are more suitable for user-defined interactions.

Therefore, the current syntax implies 'ALL'—meaning it returns true only when enabled within a scope that fully matches the query scope. Enabling a larger scope will always cause a smaller scope's is_enabled to return true; conversely, enabling a smaller scope does not cause a larger scope's is_enabled to return true. I believe this behavior is consistent.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: fix(lsp): allow specifying bufnr and client_id when enabling capabilities
